Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells communicate with one another through pores in the membrane called gap junction channels. Movement of molecules through the gap junction channels has been implicated in the development, differentiation and function of most cells of the body. The assembly and clustering of channels into functional gap junction plaques as well as the removal of these gap junction plaques from the cell membrane are thought to be critical to cell behavior. Gap junction plaque removal occurs by a unique internalization process in which the two opposing membranes are incorporated into the cytoplasm of one of two contacting cells, to form annular gap junction vesicles. There is strong evidence that clathrin (a protein known to be involved in endocytosis of membrane protein) and protein kinases are involved in this internalization process. In this research study, the hypothesis is that protein kinase-mediated phosphorylation of the gap junction channel protein (Connexin 43) control the recruitment of clathrin to the gap junction plaque and thus regulate gap junction plaque internalization. To test this hypothesis a combination of morphological methodologies (immunocytochemistry, live cell imaging, electron microscopy) and molecular alterations (truncations and mutations to modify critical kinase binding and/or phosphorylation sites on the gap junction protein) will be used in adrenal, uterine and ovarian cell cultures. In addition, protein kinase activity will be altered by chemical treatments, knockdown (siRNA) protocols, micro-chromophore-assisted laser inactivation of SNAP-tag proteins and infection with replication-defective adenovirus vectors. Information resulting from this study will increase our understanding of gap junction protein trafficking as well as of membrane trafficking in general. Furthermore, elucidating the mechanism of gap junction internalization will impact our capacity for targeting gap junctions for treatments to control and/or correct cell behavior.

Broader Impact
The laboratory will continue to serve as a resource for the training of high school, undergraduate and graduate students, as well as visiting professors from minority institutions. Trainees will be involved in all aspects of this project and they will be encouraged to write and present their findings in the research laboratory, both to the scientific community and to the general public. In addition to obtaining instructions and experience with the tools of cell and molecular biology, students will receive training in public speaking, grant writing, manuscript preparation, laboratory operations, and career management. Through publications, seminars, lectures and workshops, presented both nationally and internationally, the research team is expected to make an impact on the scientific community. Novel methods, such as instillation art, for demonstrating processes in cell biology and for engaging and educating the general public.

OUTCOME

Gap junctions are channels that allow cells to pass molecules directly from the cytoplasm of one cell to another, thereby regulating and coordinating a variety of different cell behaviors.  These channels are clustered into membrane arrays called gap junction plaques that are found on the plasma membrane of most cells of the body. Removing the channels from the cell surface alters the capacity for cells to share information with one another and thus impacts a number of important cellular events, including cell population growth, cell migration during development and response to hormones.

We have characterized the steps in gap junction plaque removal from the plasma membrane (Fig. 1) and demonstrated the interplay between clathrin, adaptor proteins, dynamin, and two protein kinases [protein kinase A (PKA) and protein kinase C (PKC)].  With combined morphological and molecular biological techniques, we provide evidence that clathrin and its adaptor proteins are recruited to the gap junction plaque in one of the two contacting cells prior to invagination (Figs. 1 and 2). Invagination of the gap junction plaque resulted in a bud-like projection from the cell surface into the cell cytoplasm of one of two contacting cells (Fig. 3).  A second molecule, dynamin, is then localized to the neck of the gap junction bud where it is thought to facilitate the scissoring of the neck of the bud (Fig. 2C). In addition, both clathrin and dynamin were found associated with annular gap junction vesicles (Fig. 2B and D). Inhibiting dynamin activity decreased not only annular gap junction formation but also its fission (Fig. 4).  It is thus suggested, based on dynamin’s location on or near the equatorial plane of annular gap junction vesicles, and the decrease in annular fission events when dynamin was inhibited (Fig. 4H), that dynamin constricts the vesicle until it divides into smaller gap junction vesicles. The fission of the annular gap junction was an unexpected finding. This fission process may be needed for either efficient degradation of gap junction channels or delivery of gap junction channel proteins (connexins) back to the plasma membrane.

The role of the protein kinases, PKC and PKA, in modulating  steps in gap junction plaque internalization was investigated. Activating protein kinase C increased clathrin-mediated gap junction internalization while also increasing the number of annular gap junction vesicles found in the cytoplasm. However, PKA activation decreased internalization and resulted in fewer annular gap junctions. Our unexpected finding that annular gap junctions undergo fissions to form smaller annular gap junction vesicles (Fig.4) could have a tremendous impact on the analysis and interpretation of gap junction internalization data. We suggest that the change in annular gap junction vesicle numbers following treatments that altered PKA or PKC may reflect a change in the number of annular gap junction fissions in addition to changes in the number of gap junction plaque internalization events.

 

 KEY OUTCOME

Clathrin is recruited to the gap junction plaque and facilitates plaque invagination. Subsequent to this event, we have demonstrated that a dynamin-mediated fission of the necks of the invaginated gap junction plaques results in the release of nascent double-membraned annular gap junction vesicles into the cytoplasm of one cell of the cell pair. These annular gap junction vesicles were further processed by a dynamin-medicated fission process that resulted in the formation of smaller annular gap junction vesicles.  Altering PKA stabilizes the gap junction plaques at the cell surface, while altering PKC levels, increases Cx43 phosphorylation and results in increased gap junction plaque internalization.
